Call or text 988 or chat 988lifeline.org. The 988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline is a national network of local crisis centers that provides free and confidential emotional support to people in suicidal crisis or emotional distress 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

The national Disaster Distress Helpline is available for anyone experiencing emotional distress related to natural or human-caused disasters.Call or text 1-800-985-5990 to be connected to a trained, caring counselor, 24/7/365.
Text MHA to 741741 and you\'ll be connected to a trained Crisis Counselor. Crisis Text Line provides free, text-based support 24/7.
Call 1-866-488-7386 or text START to 678678.A national 24-hour, toll free confidential suicide hotline for LGBTQ youth.
Dial 877-565-8860 for US and 877-330-6366 for Canada.Trans Lifeline\'s Hotline is a peer support service run by trans people, for trans and questioning callers.

Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by any of the following problems?
Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by any of the following problems?

Do you enjoy a drink now and then\nMany of us do, often when socializing with friends and family. Lets take a look at your drinking patterns and how they may affect your health.\nThe AUDIT questionnaire is designed to help in the self-assessment of alcohol consumption and to identify any implications for the persons health and well being, now and in the future.

Drug use refers to the use of prescribed or over‐the‐counter drugs in excess of the directions, and any non medical use of drugs. \nThe various classes of drugs may include cannabis , solvents , tranquilizers, barbiturates, cocaine, stimulants, hallucinogens or narcotics . The questions do not include alcoholic beverages.\nPlease answer every question. If you have difficulty with a statement, then choose the response that is mostly right.

The Calmscient discovery will only be as effective as you make it. \nSo be determined to dedicate time to following along and completing the exercises. Each section has interesting and informative content that is designed to keep you actively thinking about your specific challenges. But, like taking a road trip to an unknown destination, you’ll need to be committed to following the map! It may be a little more work than you’re used to, but it will absolutely pay off in the end.

string.name: page_7.1
string.font: If a person could simply “remember” past experiences,

resources.string:
Anxiety is a normal brain response to stress. The Fight, Flight, and Freeze responses help us meet the demands of potential threats. Things that can cause anxiety are:

 • Encountering past threats
 • Unknown risks, changes, or results
 • Lack of skill or support
 Our nervous system is not broken! Learning to control it is an important and powerful skill we can master in order to keep stressful situations in their place.

Our brain is like a computer. It has a basic operating system that helps us deal with the normal, day-to-day tasks and complexities of life. But when it detects a threat that can interrupt or damage normal operation, an alarm activates that immediately alerts us to the danger.

 You can imagine why this “Threat Alert” in our nervous system always takes priority. It’s so that we can get back to normal operations as quickly as possible. When this threat system is triggered, stress responses such as Fight/Flight/Freeze are activated. Stress hormones, such as adrenaline and cortisol, flood our system in order to meet the demands of the danger. Intense emotions, such as anxiety, fear and feeling overwhelmed, can overtake our mind.

 Understandably, general brain functions slow down or may be put “on hold” until the danger is taken care of. This is why we might feel that our thinking capacity diminishes when we are experiencing anxiety. Our “Threat Alert” system is an important part of our brain function, but when it is constantly engaged, enjoying life or having a full sense of self becomes difficult and may even feel out of reach.

 What are some things that can activate our “Threat Alert” system? They can be:
 …the thought that we might encounter situations or people that threatened us in the past.
 …unknown risks, unknown changes or unknown results when making a decision.
 …facing a challenging situation that we don’t think we have enough skills or support to overcome.

 Remember: anxiety is a normal brain response to stress. Our nervous system is not broken and there is nothing wrong with us when we feel anxious! Learning to control it is an important and powerful skill we can master in order to keep stressful situations in their place.

A calm mind can only start with a calm body. Why is that?

 Remember: anxiety is our body’s response to danger, whether real or imagined. So if we can control our body, we can suppress our mind from responding with overwhelming worry and rumination.

 The very beginning of anxiety starts with “body sensations”. As soon as we perceive them, we will learn to “press pause”, so to speak. Our goal is to lower our stress hormones and this will result in stabilizing our nervous system.
 Some of the best techniques include exercises for mindful breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, body movement and resource installation.

 These exercises will calm your stress response and give you the space to handle anxious thoughts and build healthy behaviors. This will result in physical and emotional betterment.

 Why don’t you practice some of these exercises for ten minutes every morning or right before bedtime? The key is consistency so that your body learns what it feels like to have a calm nervous system.
